data.name: FleeExpressionCondition`1_FleeExpression.Help
data.value:
Enter here a boolean expression to be matched as a condition to trigger the sub strategy.

The expression is evaluated using Fast Lightweight Expression Evaluator, an open source expression engine, which allows fast computation thanks to byte code emission.

  • All expressions are dynamically built on first call and then cached for very fast retrieval and evaluation.
  • You should refer to the language reference to build your expressions.
  • The engine uses static type imports to enhance the set of available methods. the import includes all methods from the "System.Math" static class and all methods from the default types (object, int, char, string etc.)
  • The engine uses the concept of a dedicated Expression owner to supply the available variables. The expression owner is of type "Aricie.DNN.Modules.PortalKeeper.PortalKeeperContext, Aricie.PortalKeeper", which contains many properties giving access to the Http and DotNetNuke context.
  • If your expression does not evaluate properly, you should find exception reports in the DNN event log with hints for a correction

    • Here are a couple of sample valid expressions to get you started:

  • Match if the current user is authenticated:
    DnnContext.IsAuthenticated
  • Match if the current user is a member of the dnn role "Customers":
    DnnContext.User.IsInRole("Customers")
  • Match if the current request is secure (Https):
    DnnContext.HttpContext.Request.IsSecureConnection()
  • Match if the current user email contains "aricie.fr":
    DnnContext.User.Email.Contains("aricie.fr")
  • Match if the current page name contains "secure"
    DnnContext.Portal.ActiveTab.TabName.contains("secure")

data.name: FirewallConfig_RecoveryParam.Help
data.value:
Portal Keeper applies restrictions on authorized accesses to your portal according to specific conditions; accordingly you might find yourself locked out without a mean to log as an admin user anymore (for instance if your ISP changes your static IP without prior notice... yes, we had that one once !).

Enter here a secret string, which when found in the url -for instance as a querystring parameter- will temporarily disable the firewall. Make sure to choose a complex string, to test it with your target settings enabled, and keep it in a safe location

data.name: StringTransformInfo_FilterType.Help
data.value:
Choose here the type of transformation you wish to define. There are three types available:

  • Regex transforms let you enter a source regular expression to match and replacement expression.
  • String transforms let you enter a source string and a replacement string or nothing to remove the string
  • Chars transforms let you enter a source list of chars as a concatenated string and either
    • a concatenated string of the same size for a char by char replacement mapping
    • an empty string to remove all of the source chars
    • a single char to replace each of the source chars with the single target char

data.name: StringTransformInfo_Replace.Help
data.value: Enter the target regex pattern/string/chars according to the type of filter selected. For char replaces, leave empty to remove source chars, enter a single char to replace all source chars by the single target char, or enter the same number of chars as in source value, for individual char replacements.

data.name: FirewallConfig_EnablePortalLevelSettings.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable portal specific settings. If enabled portal administrators will get access to a restricted set of parameters, which will be merged at runtime with the host configuration. Beware that the admin config is not available before the end of the begin request event.

data.name: FirewallConfig_EnableStopWatch.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable a stop watch to record request event timings in dnn event log. The "DebugInfo" Log type must be activated. The measurements give indications of the firewall overhead.

data.name: ProviderConfig_TypeName.Required
data.value: A Provider type name is needed. Generic types can be entered following the existing examples' syntax

data.name: RequestsCapInfo_MaxNbNewSources.Help
data.value: In order to account for widely distributed attacks, you can optionally define a max number of new sources accepted per duration. If that cap is reached during any "time window" of the configured duration. Such a window is banned as a whole instead of only the corresponding source. As a consequence, any client, which connected for the first time during the same window will match regardless its individual request rate. Accordingly, this may result in banning a handful of legitimate users, yet provides a very robust additional protection against widespread attacks, where no single client rate matched yet a very large number of clients suddenly request the server over a short period of time.

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_ParseCultureMode.Help

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_StaticImports.Text

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_Variables.Help
data.value:
In order for the expression to compile, variables must be explicitally typed. The set of available types can be updated in the next section.
There are 2 types of variables:
  • CtorVariable, only available when the target type has a default parameterless constructor, which resolve through calling the corresponding constructor.
  • ExpressionVariable, which is made from a complete sub Flee Expression
    • /ul>

data.name: FleeImportInfo_CustomNamespace.Help
data.value: When importing the static functions of a class, you can optionally attach them to a so-called "namespace", which then is used as a prefix to the function calls, e.g. Import System.Math with namespace "math", use math.cos()

data.name: VariableInfo_EvaluationMode.Help
data.value: There are 2 modes of evaluation, Constant, which means the variable is only computed on the first evaluation and then Dynamic, which means the variable is computed on each evaluation and may depend on the context. Flee engine can deal with chaining comiled sub-expression to keep performances optimal.

data.name: Variables_ExpressionTypes.Help

data.name: Variables_ExpressionTypes.Text

data.name: ExpressionVariableInfo`1_FleeExpression.Help

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_Variables.Help
data.value:
You can use any parameter defined here by its name in any expression based condition/action. You can update the list of .Net types available below. For each .Net type, you can choose amongst at most 3 kinds of variables to define a new parameter:
  • VariableInfo : An instance of the .Net type will be created and saved together with the configuration. You can edit the properties for that instance directly in the configuration form
  • cTorVariableInfo : your parameter is created by calling a constructor of the corresponding .Net type. You can choose to pass parameters to the constructor.
  • ExpressionVariableInfo : your parameter is defined by evaluating a Flee expression (see the corresponding help lables for more information).

Profile Property lets you define the Field as in DNN's native profile property editor.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_EncryptionKey.Help
data.value: In order to secure user data, it is encrypted using Rijndael provider with a symmetrical key and a salt from the user's email address. Accordingly, users should backup their bot parameters before they update their profile email address. The encryption key itself is stored encrypted against a fingerprint of the current DNN hosting Instance.

data.name: ExchangeInfo_AskCommission.Help
data.value: This is the transaction fee in percentage applied on ask orders

data.name: ExchangeInfo_BidCommission.Help
data.value: This is the transaction fee in percentage applied on bid orders. It may be different from the Ask Commission when a double commission is applied on the order value and on the amount purchased.

data.name: ExchangeInfo_Filter.Help
data.value: If the API does not match exactly the expected format, you may be able to fix the response String from API calls to get it to work

data.name: ExchangeInfo_TradingUrls.Help
data.value: Enter here the urls for various operations supported. The default bot expect json responses modeled against MtGox API

data.name: ExchangeInfo_AmountDecil.Help
data.value: This is the number of decimals the exchange takes for order amounts

data.name: ExchangeInfo_MinOrderAmount.Help
data.value: This is the amount for the lowest ask / highest bid issuable by the bot

data.name: ExchangeInfo_PriceDecil.Help
data.value: This is the number of decimals the exchange takes for order prices

data.name: TradingStrategy_AdjustOrderLimitRate.Help
data.value: This is the limit, below which an order is increased, in percentage of the ideal amount defined by the amount expression

data.name: TradingStrategy_LimitOrderValueRate.Help
data.value:
(% Max Order Value)
The pricer defines a profit margin band around the current price where no order is issued. This parameter defines the value of the limit central orders as a percentage of the outer orders.

data.name: TradingStrategy_DefaultMaxOrderValueRate.Help
data.value:
(Value % available btc/$ )
When defining a new band, this the percentage of available resource allocated to the upper/lower bound order

data.name: TradingStrategy_DefaultBandWidthRate.Help
data.value:
(Current Price +- X %)
This defines the default upper/lower orders, within which the trading bot will place other open orders. Manual orders can discard this value, which is only used when there is no ask/bid existing order.

data.name: TradingStrategy_VolumeGrowthLimitFactor.Help
data.value: This accounts for adjusting the trading band by increasing the outer bound orders thus the trading volume, when the available resources increase. If the extreme orders value multiplied by this parameter are found to be less than the available resource, those orders are increased using the following parameter.

data.name: TradingStrategy_VolumeGrowthRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of available resource used to increase the amount of the corresponding outer order

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_EnableStopWatch.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable a stop watch to record engine event timings in dnn event log. The "DebugInfo" Log type must be activated. The measurements give indications of the firewall overhead.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SleepTime.Help
data.value: You can optionally define a period to wait after the action is performed

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_AskReserveRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of btcs you keep off trading. Note that if the available resource decrease, so does the reserved resource

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_BidReserveRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of usds you keep off trading. Note that if the available resource decrease, so does the reserved resource

data.name: TradingStrategy_LimitOrderMarginRate.Help
data.value:
(% Order Price)
The central margin band where no orders are issued is defined by the exchange transaction fee and an additional margin defined by this parameter as a percentage of the current price.

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_EnableSimpleLogs.Help
data.value: The Debug Timer generates a lot of dnn events for each. The simple logger only logs run start/end together with dumped variables serialized if enabled

data.name: TradingStrategy_BandWidthMarginRate.Help
data.value: If the ticker gets too close to one of the extreme orders by this percentage, a new bandwidth is defined and the open orders broken up to this new band.

data.name: TradingStrategy_InterTradeReserve.Help
data.value: This the percentage of resources alocated to trading reserved for subsequent bot run.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_AlternateAction.Help

data.name: ActionProvider`1_Condition.Help

data.name: ActionProvider`1_ConditionalAction.Help

data.name: TradingStrategy_CancelOrderLimitRate.Help
data.value: In case of varying order density, this attempts to maintain the desired price distribution/density. An order is cancelled if the span between that order and the next one is found smaller than the following span by less than the percentage defined by this parameter.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_AddSleepTime.Help
data.value: You can optionally define a time span to wait after the action was performed. This is useful for instance if you're constrained by rate cap on external web requests.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_Bots.Help
data.value: Each bot has its own schedule and rule engine. You may use the import/export feature to copy elements between bots, yet you should always start with making sure that the target bot has got the needed providers properly registered.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_DisplayBotConfig.Help

data.name: FirewallConfig_RestartParam.Help

data.name: TradingStrategy_AskOrderAmountExpression.Help

data.name: TradingStrategy_BidOrderAmountExpression.Help
data.value: This is the expression to compute a bid order amount given its price. It is used both for new orders and existing order updates. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: TradingStrategy_MaxBidOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: This defines how new inner bid orders are defined starting from the highest existing bid order, getting closer to the current price, until the central margin band is reached.. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: TradingStrategy_MinAskOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: This defines how new inner ask orders are defined starting from the lowest existing ask order, getting closer to the current price, until the central margin band is reached.. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.value: This sets an outer bound for the trading band outer orders. When outside of that bound, the corresponding half band is redefined.

data.name: TradingStrategy_MinBandWidthRate.Help
data.value: This sets an inner bound for the trading band outer orders. When outside of that bound, the corresponding half band is redefined.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_Schedule.Help
data.value:
The DNN scheduler task running the farm is set to run every minute.

Now each bot can be individually scheduled to a shorter period. Accordingly, this minimum schedule allows to run the farm several times within each DNN scheduler period. The corresponding sub period should be less than the shortest bot period. Also, if you have several bots, some of which require a lengthy execution, you should make sure to configure them to run asynchronously.

Note, that unless you get a constant traffic, you'll get the most accurate results with timer mode. The asynchronous autoping bot helps mitigating that effect

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_FirewallConfig.Help
data.value: This first tab contains the configuration form for the firewall and custom errors. The firewall engine contains rules, which deal with processing incoming requests.

data.name: BotInfo`1_RunningServers.Help
data.value: In case of a web farm, you can optionnally enter a comma separated list of server names, on which the bot will exclusively be run.

data.name: TradingStrategy_VolumeResetLimitFactor.Help
data.value: If an extreme order value multiplied by this factor becomes higher than the available resources of that kind, then all open orders of that kind are cancelled to reset the band.

data.name: WebAction`1_HeaderParameters.Help
data.value: You can specify static or variable parameters to be included in the http request header.

data.name: WebRequestInfo`1_RetryNb.Help

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_EnableLogs.Help
data.value: When enabled, a dnn event log is created at the beginning and at the end of each web farm run. Event log is of log type "Debug", which isn't monitored by default.

data.name: LocationSettings_BackupsNb.Help

data.name: BotInfoEvent_PayLoad.Help

data.name: UserBotInfo_NoOverride.Help
data.value: The platform allows site administrators to occasionally propose updated default values for selected variable to be overwritten, typically with better values. When checked, your set of variables won't be overwritten when given the opportunity, unless the overwrite is explicitly forced. A platform administrator should warn you when such an upgrade opportunity is given.

data.name: UserVariableInfo_ForceOverride.Help
data.value: When checked, all user values will be overriden with the default value regardless of their choice to lock their value

data.name: UserVariableInfo_Override.Help
data.value: When checked the default bot variable value will replace any previously saved user value on subsequent bot runs. Users can choose to lock their variables unless the override is forced.

data.name: WebBotHistory_BotCallHistory.Help
data.value: You'll find here detailed information about the last bot runs, which can prove helpful to diagnose potential issues

data.name: UserBotSettings`1_FormerName.Help
data.value: User bots are saved as serialized, compressed and encrypted in user personalisation profiles entries registered with a key depending on the user bot names. If you change the user bot name, you can provide here the previous name to have the existing user bots properly migrated with the new key.

data.name: APICredentials_Key.Help

data.name: WebAction`1_IncludePostData.Help

Check here to derive the post data from the above parameters and include them as an additional variable string available to compute the headers variables.

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_AskReserveAmount.Help

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_BidReserveValue.Help

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_NoBids.Help

data.name: DefineVarsActionProvider`1_GetFromHistory.Help
data.value:
When checked, the variables defined here are checked for the existence of an existing version within the execution context with the same name prefixed with "Last"; Any existing version replaces the new definition.

That allows you to define variables to be reused between each run, with a bot History configured to load last variable dump from history (from within the Bot History tab: previous run variables are loaded with their original key prefixed with "Last")

data.name: TradingSeries_TotalEarningsFixedPrice.Help
data.value: Same except that the previous balance is computed with current price ( = usds + btcs * lastprice)

data.name: TradingSeries_TotalEarningsRateFixedPrice.Help
data.value: Same except that the previous balance is computed with current price ( = usds + btcs * lastprice)

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_RealLiteralDataType.Help

data.name: TradingStrategy_NextAskOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: When trading outwards, the first order is defined by the margin band, further orders are defined using the following expression. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext

data.name: TradingStrategy_NextBidOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: When trading outwards, the first order is defined by the margin band, further orders are defined using the following expression. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext

data.name: TradingStrategy_TradingBandDirection.Help
data.value: Once the outer orders of the trading band are defined according to the parameters, inner orders are defined based on custom arithmetic expressions. You can choose to define the innter orders outwards, starting from a price limit defined by the margin band, or inwards, starting with the existing open orders towards the limit band.

data.name: UserVariableInfo_IsReadOnly.Help
data.value: When checked, the form version of the parameter is discarded upon saving

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_MutexName.Help

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_SynchronisationTimeout.Help

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_Synchronization.Help
data.value: Depending on your hosting environment (several instances, web gardening, old dnn scheduler etc.), you might find yourself with the scheduling taks running simultaneously in distinct threads/processus. As this could be detrimental in case of critical bots, you can choose here how the farm locks upon running. Note that using a Mutex requires elevated Full trust permissions.

data.name: TradingStrategy_AccountForTrend.Help
data.value: When checked, the bot avoid issueing inner band asks when the amount of btcs is found to decrease in the recent history, and similarly bids when the total of btcs is found to increase. This is a simple mechanism to prevent the same types of orders to be issued and executed several times in a row when the price oscillates between successive runs.

data.name: TradingHistory_FiveMinEvents.Text

data.name: TradingStrategy_TakeMarginOnOppositeOrder.Help

data.name: SimulationInfo_FastSimulation.Help

Enabling fast simulation mode attempts to detect those period an skip running the bot until an existing open order gets executed or a significant price variation is observed. This allows for much faster simulations, yet you should check that the results fit the regular mode upon validating a new strategy.

data.value: Number of concurrent threads allowed by the semaphore to enter the named section (system-wide)

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SemaphoreName.Help
data.value: This is the system-wide name that will indentify your blocking semaphore. Example: HttpRequest-www.cryptsy.com

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SynchronisationTimeout.Help
data.value: Set a non zero value if you want a blocked thread to give up waiting after a time out. In such a case, the action is skipped and returns false

data.name: ActionProvider`1_UseSemaphore.Help
data.value: When you start running agents or actions asynchronously, you may observe that several actions run simultaneously. This might be detrimental in certain cases: for instance you may want to control the rate of concurrent http requests to a particular domain to avoid reaching advertised limits. Using a semaphore ensures that only a certain amount of concurrent threads can enter a named section simulatneously. Use that mechanims together with the addition of sleep time to precisally adjut the running rate. Also, if you run a web farm, you might have to make sure that your bot is configured to run on a single server.

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_EnablePerformanceCounters.Help
data.value: If checked, this enable collecting Smart Thread Pool performances to a dedicated Windows Performance Counter

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_PerformanceCounterInstanceName.Help
data.value: The Name of your custom Data collector. Since all asynchronous queues will log the same metrics, choose a name to identify this particular queue.

data.name: UserBotInfo_IsAuthenticated.Help
data.value: That indicator determines whether the user can save edits of the user bot parameters

data.name: UserVariableInfo_UseSubStorage.Help

data.name: RequestsCapInfo_Decription.Help

data.name: ActionProvider`1_DisablePerformanceLogger.Help

data.name: LoopActionProvider`1_AgregateLogSteps.Help

data.name: BotInfo`1_RunSeveralInstances.Help
data.value: You can optionnally start several instances of the bot. This might be useful when running bots asynchronously.

data.name: BotInfo`1_SharedContext.Help
data.value: When several instances are started, the initial bot context is cloned for a fresh start on each run. Sharing the context saves some time, but it will certainly bring erroneous results, although Monitors are generally used to prevent cross thread locks.

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_IdleTimeout.Help
data.value: The Task Queue engine uses the smartthreadpool component, which is capable of adjusting the number of active threads up to the specified thread number. When a thread is idle, it is stopped after the given timeout to free resources.

data.name: ControlAdaptersConfig_Enabled.Help
data.value: This is a central switch to activate or deactivate all control adapters defined here.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedControlPath.Help
data.value: Enter the path of an aspx page or an ascx user control to be adapted. The corresponding control will be loaded once at runtime to figure out its generated type.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedControlType.Help
data.value: The is the qualified .Net type of the control to be adapted.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedMode.Help
data.value: You can either designate a control to be adapted by its .Net type name, or by its path for a Page or a User Control. The latter is paticularly userful with codefile user control, the assembly of which might be unknown at runtime. The underlying .Net type is obtained by instanciating the control once.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdapterControlType.Help
data.value: The is the qualified .Net type of the adapter control class; it should inherit directly or indirectly from the ControlAdapter base class.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdapterMode.Help
data.value: There are 2 Control Adapter modes: Type, where you enter the .Net type name of a class, that inherits the base ControlAdapter or WebControlAdapter classes, or Dynamic Adapters, which are handlers built with the same engine as the firewall or scheduled bots.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_DynamicHandlers.Help
data.value: Dynamic Handlers are individual actions to be attached to a life cycle event of a control or a child control .

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_HandlerRegistrationStep.Help
data.value: If some your dynamic handlers are hooked to control or child controls events, you need to specify when to register those event handlers, depending on when the controls are available for hooking.

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_BaseHandlerMode.Help
data.value: This indicates when the native handler should run before, after, the dynamic handler, or if the original handler must be removed (only available for overrides atm, but events shouldn't be too hard to support).

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_ChildControlId.Help
data.value: If the dynamic handler is configured to handle a child control event, the child control to be hooked is found by its id.

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_ControlEventName.Help
data.value: In order to hook the dynamic handler up to the adapted control or one of its child controls event, you must provide the event name.

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_MainControlStep.Help
data.value: Defines when to run the configured handler. It can be associated to one of the available overrides, a control's event or a child control's event.

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_ControlAdapters.Help
data.value: In this section, you manage a collection of control adapters, to be dynamically registered during asp.net lifecycle. They can be traditional strongly typed Control adapters, or dynamical adapters leveraging the same engine as the firewall and schedule bots.

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_ControlAdapters.Text

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings`1_EventControlTypeAsString.Help

If the targeted child control does not correspond to a field, yet is still available through a FindControl(id) call, you can safely ignore it.

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_PortalId.Help
data.value: This is the target user's portal

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_ProfileType.Help
data.value:
There are 2 user profile which you can access:
  • the identity user profile (with a dedicated form, which the user can edit).
    • ,
  • the personalization user profile (that one is rarely used and does not have an edit form associated, it is intended to customize user experience).

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_PropertyName.Help
data.value: This is the name of the profile property to access

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_UserMode.Help
data.value:
There are several ways to select the user, the profile of which to be accessed:
  • Current user: implies that the action is run in an authenticated context, the authenticated user is choosen
  • By User Id: you have to explicitally indicate the portal and the user id or an integer expression that resolves into the user id
  • By Username : you have to explicitally indicate the portal and the target user's Username or a string expression that resolves into the username
  • By Userinfo: You have to supply a UserInfo expression that resolves into the targetted user entity

data.name: ProfileSaveActionProvider`1_Value.Help

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_Mode.Help

data.name: SimpleExpression`1_Expression.Required

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_NewOwner.Help
data.value: Enter here a Flee expression that will be evaluated in order to provide a new dedicated Expression Owner to the main expression. All members from the new owner (including private fields) are then available in the main expression.

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_OverrideOwner.Help
data.value: The Flee Compiler used for code expressions has the underlying concept of an Expression Owner. By default, the current instance of PortalKeeperContext is passed as an expression owner of all expressions. You can alternatively supply a simple expression that resolves into the desired context owner. One big advantage is the posibility to access private members without relying on time consuming Reflection operations.

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_NamingContainer.Help

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_NamingContainer.Required

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_UserInfoExpression.Help

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_UsernameExpression.Help

data.name: SimpleOrExpression`1_EditableExpression.Help

data.name: Variables_AddDelegates.Help

data.name: WebProxyInfo_VirtualProxy.Help

data.name: EncryptionInfo_SealType.Help
data.value:
The encryption keys are initially kept visible and editable. You can hide them by sealing them in 3 optional passes:
  • An Application level seal encrypts the private key with the main application decryption key. Only the same DNN application will be able to recover the key at runtime.
  • A Key Container seal creates a dedicated OS Level CSPContainer Key to encrypt the private key. Only the same system will be able to recover the key at runtime.
  • A Protected Data seal encrypts the private key using the native ProtectedData methods from win32 DAPI.Only the same system and application pool identity user will be able to recover the key at runtime.
In order to seal your keys, click one of the corresponding button at the bottom of this form, after having saved the original values. Note that if you need to move the application to a new environment, you won't be able to recover the keys unless you do a reset and manually enter the original values.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_ProtectInMemory.Help
data.value: Checking that option ofuscate the symmetric key in memory to avoid recollection from a dump.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyAsRSAParameters.Help
data.value: This is the base64 representation of an instance of the RSAParameters structure, from an export from the public key derived from the asymmetrical private key.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyAsXml.Help
data.value: This is the Xml string format of the public key derived from the asymmetrical private key as returned by AsymmetricalAlgorithm.ExportXml(false)

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyDisplay.Help
data.value: You can choose to display the public key in various format: Xml parameters, CspBlob or RSAParameters

data.name: EncryptionInfo_SelectedEncryptionType.Help

data.name: HttpHandlersConfig_DefaultFiddle.Help
data.value: A fiddle is a test environment for a handler. Dynamic Http Handlers support sub-handlers which can be of any kind such as an Html Page. When configuring a new handler, the use for a test page is not uncommon and provided by a command button available in the sub handlers menu. This is the template sub-handlers that the dedicated fiddle will be cloned from, and further customized.

data.name: HttpHandlerSettings_SubHandlers.Help
data.value: You can build compound handlers by refining verb and path selection, while setting intermediate parameters within the resulting decision tree. the "Create a Test Fiddle" button leverages that feature to create a test Html page to your handler with associated resources.

data.name: HttpSubHandlerSettings_InitParamsToSubHandler.Help
data.value: By default, the params of the main dynamic handler engine are added to a sub handler params before it is run. Uncheck to remove the main handler parameters from the sub handler.

data.name: HttpSubHandlerSettings_RunMainHandler.Help

data.name: TokenizedTextInfo_AddNewTokenSources.Help
data.value: You can add several kinds of token sources, generally associated to prefixes. Static Tokens are native to DNN and must be upper case underscore and digits only (no prefixing). Token Providers are self contained classes, the public members of which will be exposed. Conditional Tokens let you define token sources according to other tokens value. Tokens Variables are custom variables as instances or dynamic expressions, fed to the token replace component as with token providers.

data.name: CacheableAction`1_SemaphoreAppliesToCache.Help

data.name: TestFiddleAdded.Message

data.name: ScheduleInfo_DayMode.Help
data.value:
There are 3 day modes available:
  • Every means the bot will run every day
  • Once means the bot will run one one day of a week at the first opportunity, without any retargeting
  • Specificsmeans you get to choose the scheduled week days

data.name: ScheduleInfo_FormattedValue.Help
data.value: This is a summary of your current schedule. Note that you can see it abreviated in the Bot header link for concision.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_FormattedValueShort.Help
data.value: This is the short version that will be used as a shortcut in other place.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_HourMode.Help
data.value:
There are 3 hours modes available:
  • Every means the bot will run every hour
  • Once means the bot will run once a day at the first opportunity, and retarget to the next day midnight.
  • Specificsmeans you get to choose the scheduled hours

data.name: ScheduleInfo_MonthMode.Help
data.value:
There are 3 Month modes available:
  • Every means the bot will run every month
  • Once means the bot will run on one month of the year at the first opportunity, retargeting to next years's january.
  • Specificsmeans you get to choose the scheduled month

data.name: ScheduleInfo_Period.Help
data.value: This is the target period between 2 runs of your bot.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_ScheduleType.Help
data.value:
There are 2 modes.
  • Period will let you enter a time span.
  • Fixed times will let you choose fixed hours and date events
    • Combined will run the bot on the periodic schedule within the fixed slots configured. This is meaningful with quite short periods

data.name: ScheduleInfo_SpecificDays.Help
data.value: Choose here the specific hours when you want your bot to run.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_SpecificHours.Help
data.value: Choose here the specific hours when you want your bot to run.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_SpecificMonths.Help
data.value: Choose here the specific months when you want your bot to run.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_SpecificWeeks.Help
data.value: Choose here the specific weeks of the month when you want your bot to run.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_SpecificYears.Help
data.value: Manage here the specific years when you want your bot to run.

data.name: ScheduleInfo_WeekMode.Help
data.value:
There are 3 week modes available:
  • Every means the bot will run every week
  • Once means the bot will run on one week of the month at the first opportunity, retargeting to the next month's first week.
  • Specificsmeans you get to choose the scheduled month weeks

data.name: ScheduleInfo_YearMode.Help
data.value:
There are 3 year modes available:
  • Every means the bot will run every year
  • Once means the bot will run only once. Any existing history will cause the bot to stop running
  • Specificsmeans you get to choose the years by managing a list of integers.

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_LoggingLevel.Help
data.value:
You can generate DNN event logs of type DebugInfo, which must be activated in the Event Viewer Module settings first. There are 3 levels of logging.
  • Simple means just the start and end events of the agent together with a dump if applicable
  • Steps means all engine steps or state changes are logged
  • Detailed means all individual condition and actions are logged.

Here, as single salt is generated and reused. The result is then converted to base 64, and decryption assumes a base 64 string. You'll need to copy the keys and salt for both operations to match.

data.name: OutputCachingStrategy_AddArrOptOutHeaders.Help
data.value: Since IIS standard load-balancer, Application Request Routing (ARR), adds affinity cookies to the http responses to route the clients to a a single server, that would also concern all clients using a single cached version. Fortunately, since ARR version 3.0, Microsoft provides an opt-out mechanism through a dedicated header, which prevents the cookie from being generated. Check here to opt out from ARR affinity by generating such a response header.

data.name: UrlCompressionInfo_DoDynamicCompression.Help

data.name: UrlCompressionInfo_DoStaticCompression.Help
data.value: Indicates whether static files should be compressed, as opposed to dynamic pages and content. Note that in order to define the corresponding web.config file section, it must not be forbiden at the web site level.

data.name: UrlCompressionInfo_DynamicCompressionBeforeCache.Help
data.value: When using dynamic compression in conjunction with output caching, you may define here that compression should be done before caching. Make sure that you set a VaryByContentEncoding="gzip;deflate" directive to properly support clients with various compression policies, and be aware that this disables kernel caching, thus at a small cost, that might be compensated by the gain in CPU and bandwidth.

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_ExtraParameters.Help
data.value: ExtraParameters holds a string that just gets added to the query string per se. The parameter should honor URL encoding, the library will not touch its value, but just append it to the existing query. The URL parameter characters will be inserted by the FeedQuery object.

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_FeedFormat.Help
data.value: One of the supported GData feed formats

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_MaxPublication.Help
data.value: sets the maximum (inclusive) publication date/time value for the requested element

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_MinPublication.Help
data.value: sets the mininum (inclusive) publication date/time value for the requested element

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_ModifiedSince.Help
data.value: sets the ModifiedSince date. If this is set to something different than DateTime.MinValue, and the FeedQuery object is used for a Service.Query call, this will cause an ifmodified Since header to be created.

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_NumberToRetrieve.Help
data.value: the number of entries to retrieve

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_Query.Help
data.value: Gets or Sets the q query string parameter of the feed query

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_StartDate.Help
data.value: sets the mininum (inclusive) date/time value for the requested element

data.name: FeedQueryInfo_StartIndex.Help
data.value: the start-index query parameter, a 1-based index indicating the first result to be retrieved.

data.name: GoogleSpreadSheetActionProvider`1_Query.Help
data.value: You can optionally add a series of filtering parameters to your query

data.name: InstanceReset.Message
data.value: Instance was reset to be created again

data.name: ListQueryInfo_OrderByColumn.Help
data.value: The header of the column to sort results by. Sets OrderByPosition to false. Important: The column name used in the orderby parameter is case sensitive and must match the name of the column as it appears in the API. The column names are the header values of the worksheet lowercased and with all non-alpha-numeric characters removed. For example, if the cell A1 contains the value "Time 2 Eat!" the column name would be "time2eat".

data.name: ListQueryInfo_OrderByPosition.Help
data.value: If true, then results will be ordered by the position in the spreadsheet. Sets OrderByColumn to null.

data.name: ListQueryInfo_Reverse.Help
data.value: If true, then however the results are ordered will be reversed.

data.name: ListQueryInfo_SpreadsheetQuery.Help
data.value: A spreadsheet query string, if set to a non-null value, then the FullTextQuery will be set to null

data.name: ParametersCreated.Message
data.value: A set of named and typed Parameters was sucessfully initialized according to the selected method signature.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_CustomDictionaryToObject.Help
data.value: You can choose to define the building of the custom object explicitly in the form of a list of object variables making for the property names and corresponding typed values to be updated over a new instantiated object.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_CustomDictionaryVariableName.Help
data.value: In order to build the property dictionary of typed values, the string dictionary is inserted in the available contextual variables with the following name.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_CustomObjectToDictionary.Help
data.value: You can choose to define the building of the dictionary explicitly in the form of a list of string variables making for the keys and values to be inserted.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_CustomObjectVariableName.Help
data.value: In order to build the dictionary, the object is inserted in the available contextual variables with the following name.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_SelectedType.Help

data.name: AmbiguousAction.Message

data.name: CreateHttpResponseInfo_CustomHttpHeaders.Help
data.value: You can optionally define custom http headers to return together with your http response. Define corresponding variables with key the http hreader name and value type either string or some enumerable of string depending whether the target http header accepts a value or a collection of values.

data.name: CulturePicker_CultureMode.Help
data.value: You can choose to pick an invariant, the current culture or to select a culture manually

data.name: DynamicControllerInfo_SpecificRoutes.Help
data.value: Those routes are registered at the controller level.

data.name: RestServicesSettings_GlobalRoutes.Help
data.value: Those are routes available to all services. Note that because of the way web API and DNN deal with routes, it is important that general purpose rules be registered after more specific rules to resolve ambiguities. Accordingly, those routes are registered at the end, and you should account for that when ordering your services, controllers and routes.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_CreateEmptyObjects.Help
data.value: Check if you want structured objects to be initialized from empty strings rather than set to null at deserialization time.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_InitializeLists.Help
data.value: For test purpose, you can also automatically add a single item to empty lists from empty strings.

data.name: TypeDictionaryConverter_ParsingCulture.Help
data.value: When converting typed properties to and from target strings, define what culture to use

data.name: AddNew.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Adds a new item at the end of the collection. For dictionaries, a new key must be provided.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_RunForcedBots.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Runs all bots with forced run enabled. Note that a bot can be disabled for scheduled execution and still included in forced runs. This is the most convenient way to develop and test your bots. Also note that user bots can still take over master bot execution if enabled.

data.name: ClearItems.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Clears all items from the collection

data.name: ClearItems.Warning
data.value: This will remove all items from the collection. Are you sure?

data.name: ControlAdaptersConfig_RegisterAdapters.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Clears the current state of registered adapters, to account for the last changes in the saved configuration.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_DowngradeDynamicHandlers.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Transforms currently typed dynamic handlers to untyped counterparts, with less configuration assistance, but required in case of user control adapters for portability. If you have user control adapters, you should upgrade before editing, and downgrade before saving.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_UpgradeDynamicHandlers.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Transforms currently untyped dynamic handlers to handlers tied to the adapted control type, with easier configuration capabilities. User controls, though, have types dynamically compiled at runtime and subject to changes. Accordingly, dynamic handlers for user control adapters should be downgraded for exports and to support future updates.

data.name: Copy.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Copies the selected item(s). You can then paste them to a compatible collection elsewhere in the form. Note that if you don't have a paste button, then the collections are deemed incompatible.

data.name: Delete.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Deletes the selected item from the collection.

data.name: Down.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Moves the selected item one down in the ordered collection.

data.name: DynamicHandlersDowngraded.Message
data.value: Dynamic Handlers were downgraded to untyped Handlers. They are now safe for export to a new instance.

data.name: DynamicHandlersUpgraded.Message
data.value: Dynamic Handlers were upgraded to typed Handlers. Don't forget to downgrade your path-defined Adapter handlers when finished editing.

data.name: Export.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Exports the selected item(s) to a file to be downloaded for offline usage.

data.name: HttpHandlerSettings_AddTestFiddle.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Adds a set of predefined sub handlers, for html, js and css content to test your dynamic handler.

data.name: Import.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Imports items from a previously exported file. Note that except for dictionaries, imported items will not overwrite existing items, it is up to you to do the clean up manually. Also, for dictionary items, if and only if a single item is imported, the currently selected key replaces the one found in the import file.

data.name: ItemAdded.Message
data.value: An item was added at the end of the collection. Click the new row to edit its property, and don't forget to save your changes when you're done.

data.name: ItemCopied.Message
data.value: The selected item was copied. You can paste and add it to a compatible collection somewhere else in the hierarchy.

data.name: ItemDeleted.Message
data.value: The selected item was deleted from the collection. Don't forget to save your changes to apply your modifications.

data.name: ItemOneDown.Message
data.value: Selected item was moved one down within the ordered collection. Don't forget to save your changes to apply your modifications.

data.name: ItemOneUp.Message
data.value: Selected item was moved one up within the ordered collection. Don't forget to save your changes to apply your modifications.

data.name: ItemsCleared.Message
data.value: The entire collection was cleared. Don't forget to save your changes to apply your modifications.

data.name: ItemsCopied.Message
data.value: The collection was copied. You can paste and add it to a compatible collection somewhere else in the hierarchy.

data.name: ItemsImported.Message
data.value: New items were read from the file and added to the collection. Don't forget to save your changes to apply your modifications.

data.name: ItemsPasted.Message
data.value: The copied items were succesfully added to the collection

data.name: ModuleConfig`2_Cancel.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Cancels all editing since last save and reloads the original form.

data.name: ModuleConfig`2_ClearSingleton.Text.ToolTip
data.value: If Singleton is define in the configuration file settings for optimal performances, manual modification of the configuration file won't be detected (that's not the case with regular cache). Click here to reload the configuration from file at any point.

data.name: ModuleConfig`2_Reset.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Resets to the default configuration. Note that all changes since installation will be lost. The default configuration file is available at the root of the Module installation folder.

data.name: ModuleConfig`2_Save.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Saves the entire configuration according to the storage settings in the top configuration file section. Note that no change is persisted until you click here, and you should not leave the page if you have modifications to save.

data.name: ModuleConfig`2_SaveLocationSettings.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Saves your new configuration storage settings. and save the configuration file accordingly.

data.name: Navigate.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Navigates to the corresponding entity with a dedicated link (click the accordion directly alternatively to browse locally with Ajax callbacks). The corresponding url can be bookmarked as a shortcut saving from having to navigate the hierarchy.

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_ImportAvailableProviders.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Analyses all available .Net type to import available condition and action providers.

data.name: SaveLocationSettings.Warning
data.value: This will change the configuration storage settings. Have you noted the new location of your configuration file?

data.name: SubPathContainer_CloseSubEditor.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Removes the hierarchical browser and reloads the main configuration form.

data.name: SubPathContainer_LevelUp.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Sets the hierarchical browser to the parent entity, one level up the currently displayed entity.

data.name: Up.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Moves the selected item one up in the ordered collection.

data.name: XmlConfigElementInfo_Install.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Registered the corresponding Xml component in the main web.config application configuration file located at the root of your web application. This will trigger an application restart.

data.name: XmlConfigElementInfo_Update.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Updates the corresponding registered Xml component in the main web.config configuration file.

data.name: ItemDisabled.Message
data.value: Selected item was disabled. Don't forget to save your changes when finished editing.

data.name: ItemEnabled.Message
data.value: Selected item was enabled. Don't forget to save your changes when finished editing.

data.name: ManualRun.Message
data.value: Forced Bots successfully run. {0} bot(s) were run

data.name: AutoLoginAction_CurrentAutoLoginInfo.Help
data.value: You can choose to manually enter login credentials, or use a system of encrypted tickets to be provided in the request.

data.name: XmlConfigElementInfo_Uninstall.Text.ToolTip
data.value: Uninstalls the corresponding xml nodes from the main application configuration file located at the root of your application. This will trigger an application restart.

data.name: ApplicationSettings_EnableCriticalChangesHandler.Help
data.value: The notification of Application level critical file and directory changes, which triggers application restarts, can be pretty hard to diagnose. Check to hook into that system event to make that application event step available in the rules of the engine.

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_ApplicationSettings.Help
data.value: Here you have application level settings and a rule engine that taps into the application start, application end, and optionally critical file change notification events.

data.name: Cut.Command.ToolTip
data.value: Click to copy and remove that item to move it to a different collection

data.name: ItemCut.Message
data.value: The selected item was cut. You can paste it in a new collection. Don't forget to save after you finished editing

data.name: ItemsCut.Message
data.value: The selected items were cut. You can paste them in a new collection. Don't forget to save after you finished editing

data.name: Paste.Command.Tooltip
data.value: Click to add your copied items to the current collection.

data.name: CreateHttpResponseInfo_CustomTypeName.Help
data.value: Enter a name to be used while compiling your custom type

data.name: EntityKeyInfo_Application.Help
data.value: If your smart files belong to a common application scope, you can set your application name here

data.name: EntityKeyInfo_Entity.Help
data.value: Sets the name of the entity that the smart file represent

data.name: EntityKeyInfo_Field.Help
data.value: Sets the name of the entity field that the smart file represent

data.name: EntityKeyInfo_PortalId.Help
data.value: This defines the target portal root folder

data.name: EntityKeyInfo_UserName.Help
data.value: Sets the username of the user that smart file belongs to

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_SetForSave.Help
data.value: If checked, the corresponding smart file will be saved at the end of the action sequence where it is used.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_SmartFileKey.Help
data.value: Smart Files are stored with a path derived from a compound key that you can define here, either with static or dynamic values.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_UseCustomFileSettings.Text
data.value: Smart File settings defining how to derive file path from entity key and whether to compress/encrypt are generally supplied globally, but you can override those settings here.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo`1_SubType.Help
data.value: You can choose to build your variable from a subtype to the target type.

data.name: ProblemInfo_GoalTest.Help
data.value: The goal test of a problem, which implements the corresponding interface, returns a a boolean to acknowledge if the state is a solution to the problem.

data.name: ProblemInfo_HeuristicFunction.Help
data.value: Optionally a problem can define a Heuristic Function, which quantifies the search value of states.

data.name: ProblemInfo_StepCostFunction.Help
data.value: Optionally a problem can define a Step Cost Function, which gives the cost of a transition given a source state, an action and a resulting state.

data.name: ProblemInfo_ActionsFunction.Help
data.value: The action function of a problem, which implements the corresponding interface, returns a list of possible actions from a given state

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_SmartFileSettings.Help
data.value: Smart Files are serialized entities saved automatically within the DNN file system, and can be used withing the agent's actions. Define here the default settings for those Smart Files

data.name: SearchAgentInfo_InitialState.Help
data.value: This is the initial state to run the problem solver, in the form of custom object with memberwise equality and hashcode permitting comparison.

data.name: SearchAgentInfo_Problem.Help
data.value: Given an environment with states to be searched, a problem defines legal actions with a successor function, success conditions with a goal test function, and optionally a step cost and a heuristic function to weight and guide space exploration.

data.name: SearchAgentInfo_Search.Help
data.value: A Search agent will apply a search strategy over a problem, given an initial state. There are several known informed and uninformed strategies available, or a custom algorithm can be applied.

data.name: SearchDemoInfo_NQueenBoardSize.Help
data.value: Choose the size N of the chess board where N Queen must be positionned

data.name: SearchDemoInfo_EightPuzzleShuffleMoves.Help
data.value: Enter the number of moves to perform when shuffling

data.name: SearchInfo_AlgorithmType.Help
data.value: You can choose to select a known search algorithm, informed or uninformed or to define a custom algorithm implementing the corresponding Search interface

data.name: SearchInfo_CustomSearchAlgorithm.Help
data.value: Use the following controls to build a object that implement the Search interface

data.name: SearchInfo_DepthLimit.Help
data.value: This is the maximum steps ahead to lookup for the depth limited algorithm

data.name: SearchInfo_KnownInformedAlgorithm.Help
data.value: Several implementations of known informed search algorithm are available for direct selection. They require the problem to offer an Heuristic in order to work properly.

data.name: SearchInfo_KnownUninformedAlgorithm.Help
data.value: Several implementations of known uninformed search algorithm are available for direct selection. They don't require a heuristic and only need a goal test function.

data.name: SearchInfo_QueueSearchType.Help
data.value: You can choose between Graph search (default, no cycles allowed) and Tree search (cycles are not checked for)

data.name: ConnectFourIDAlphaBeta.Text
data.value: Connect Four Iterative Deepening Alpha Beta

data.name: CSPInfo_CSP.Help
data.value: Enter a variable that resolves to a csp as defined by the corresponding .Net base class

data.name: CSPInfo_StateListeners.Help
data.value: Optionally define a list of state listeners to collect information during the CSP solving

data.name: CSPInfo_Strategy.Help
data.value: Enter a variable that resolves to a csp Solution Strategy as defined by the corresponding .Net interface

data.name: CSPStrategyInfo_EnableLCV.Help
data.value: optional heuristics to order the domain values of variables rather that taking them in the natural domain order.

data.name: CSPStrategyInfo_Inference.Help
data.value: Primitive operation, which tries to prune out values from the CSP which are not possible anymore when extending the given assignment to a solution. Several algorithm are available: Forward checking, AC-3 and None (domain compactification).

data.name: CSPStrategyInfo_MaxSteps.Help
data.value: Specifies the maximum steps of local search.

data.name: CSPStrategyInfo_Selection.Help
data.value: several algorithms are available for selecting unassigned variables: minimum-remaining-values heuristic, degree heuristic, and default order (no heuristic)

data.name: CSPStratetgyInfo_StrategyType.Help
data.value: The following strategies for for constraint satisfaction problem are available: A simple backtracking algorithm modeled on the recursive depth-first search, an improved backpropagation strategy with several options for inference and selection and least constraint value, and a MIN-CONFLICTS algorithm for solving CSPs by local search with a max number of steps.

data.name: DynamicConstraint_ConstraintExpression.Help
data.value: Define here an arbitrary Flee expression making use of the available variables. You must specify which variables are concerned by the contraint in the scope below.

data.name: DynamicConstraint_Scope.Help
data.value: Explicitally enter the name of the variables within the constraint (even if the expression makes it obvious)

data.name: DynamicCSPInfo_Constraints.Help
data.value: Constraints are a list of conditions that the variables must meet. Dynamic constraints are made from expressions to be evaluated, together with the list of variables involved.

data.name: DynamicCSPInfo_Domains.Help
data.value: Domains are sets of values that the variables can have. They are named and each variable must be assigned a domain. Any IEnumerable object can be assigned to a domain.

data.name: DynamicCSPInfo_VariableDomains.Help
data.value: When more than a domain is available, variable must have domains associated through a dictionary between variable names and domain names.

data.name: DynamicCSPInfo_Variables.Help
data.value: Variable are a list of items that can be labelled. simple types are directly converted to string

data.name: DynamicParameter_DefaultValue.Help
data.value: You can define a custom default value for your optional parameter.

data.name: ProblemInfo_ResultFunction.Help
data.value: A result function returns the resulting state given a start state and an action

data.name: SearchAgentInfo_HeuristicFunction.Help
data.value: You can optionally provide a state scoring heuristic function to be used by informed search algorithms

data.name: SearchDemoInfo_NQueensActions.Help
data.value: There are 2 action functions, the complete state assumes exactly one queen in each column and provides all possible queen movements in vertical direction as actions, where as the iterative assumes that queens are placed column by column, starting with an empty board, and provides queen placing actions for all non-attacked positions of the first free column
